Award.AwardTitle: SCH: EXP: Integrated Real-Time Clinical Deterioration Prediction for Hospitalized Patients and Outpatients

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Unexpected deaths of hospitalized patients continue to be common despite evidence that patients who are at risk often show signs of clinical deterioration hours in advance. Existing early warning systems have significant shortcomings because of their poor reliability and the need for monitoring by overburdened clinical staff. Almost 1 out of 5 patients are readmitted within 30 days of hospital discharge with an annual cost to tax payers of $15-17 Billion. Hence, there is an urgent need for automated early warning systems that can provide timely and accurate information.

The project seeks to integrate and mine patient data from multiple sources, including routine clinical processes, bedside monitoring, at-home sensing, and existing electronic data sources to facilitate optimized patient-centered decision making. Specifically, the project aims to develop techniques and systems to provide early warning of clinical deterioration and hospital readmission of discharged patients using a novel two-tier system. Tier 1 uses data mining algorithms on existing hospital data records to identify patients who are most at risk of clinical deterioration and readmission. Tier 2 combines clinical data with sensor data to improve the accuracy of predictions on patients who are identified as being at risk by Tier 1.

Key innovative aspects of the project include: (1) new data mining algorithms for predicting clinical deterioration and readmission from heterogeneous, multi-scale, and high-dimensional data streams; (2) an alert explanation system to identify the most relevant prognostic factors and suggests possible intervention based on novel feature ranking algorithms; (3) a novel scheme based on cost-sensitive learning to dynamically reconfigure the sensors for achieving good tradeoff between monitoring cost and effectiveness. The resulting advances in healthcare practices that are currently employed in general wards offer several key benefits including (1) reduced workload on clinical staff; (2) capability for continuous monitoring of ward patients that can be used to triage nursing efforts in order to optimize the desired clinical outcomes; (3) capability to extend hospital monitoring to patients at high-risk for hospital readmission with the attendant benefits of reducing readmissions by targeting early preemptive therapeutic interventions.

Plans for transitioning the technology to clinical practice include rigorous evaluation of the technology in real-world settings and broad dissemination of the algorithms and their open-source implementations. Some potential broader impacts of the project include improved clinical outcomes, reduced patient mortality rates and healthcare costs, and enhanced opportunities for research-based interdisciplinary training of graduate students in health informatics. Additional information about the project can be found at: http://www.cse.wustl.edu/~wenlinchen/project/clinical/

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hospitalized patients continue to suffer from sudden deterioration and unexpected deaths. This project aims at developing an automated early warning systems that can provide timely and accurate information so that sudden deterioration and hospital readmissions can reliably predicted and potentially prevented.

In this project, we have developed and studies an informational cloud encompassing data from various sources, including routine clinical processes, bedside monitoring, at-home sensing, and existing electronic data sources. We have developed novel computational methods, arising from the field of data mining and machine learning, in order to extract patterns and knowledge from the multi-source, multi-scale data in the informational cloud. We have also developed novel tools to facilitate optimized patient-centered decision making. Specifically, we aim at early warning of two negative outcomes including clinical deterioration that requires ICU transfer and hospital readmission of discharged patients.

The project has high intellectual merits. A key feature of the developed data mining system is that it incurs only low burden on healthcare staff and acceptable inconvenience to patients. To this end, we have developed a novel two-tier system. The system focuses on the large population of patients in the general hospital wards who are not in the ICU and have infrequent monitoring. Tier-1 uses data mining algorithms on existing hospital data records to identify patients who are most at risk of clinical deterioration and readmission. Patients identified as being at risk will then have a Tier-2 algorithm applied that employs non-cumbersome vital sign sensors. We have built machine learning models that can leverage both the clinical data and sensor data for effective prediction.

We have made some research innovations in this project. First, we have proposed new data mining algorithms for predicting clinical deterioration and readmission from heterogeneous, multi-scale, and high-dimensional data streams, based on technical breakthroughs in time-series mining, metric learning, deep learning, and graph mining. Second, we have developed an alert explanation system to identify the most relevant prognostic factors and suggests possible intervention based on novel feature ranking algorithms. Novel techniques have been developed to promote interpretability, actionability, and compactness of models. Third, we have developed a novel scheme based on cost-sensitive learning to dynamically reconfigure the sensors for achieving good tradeoff between monitoring cost and effectiveness.

We have carried out a rigorous clinical study at the Barnes-Jewish Hospital to evaluate key components of the proposed system. The results have shown that our system is effective in predicting sudden deterioration and  reducing ICU transfers. Moreover, The results show that our approach can effectively identify outpatients at high risk for readmission based on their at-home body sensor data. Compared to medical care methods currently employed on the general wards, our approach offers some key benefits. Our system is completely automated and will not impose additional workloads on hospital staffs. The Tier-2 sensing method is innovative and allows for continuous monitoring of ward patients which can be used to triage nursing efforts in order to maximize clinical outcomes. The adaptive configuration scheme offers hospitals flexibility and guidance in terms of application based on acuity of patients. The development of an outpatient monitoring system is innovative and extends hospital monitoring to patients at high-risk for hospital readmission with the potential of preventing many of these readmissions by targeting early preemptive therapeutic interventions.

This project has significant broader impacts. We have provided education and training for many undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students. We have presented our methods, algorithms, data and results in our conference papers and manuscripts for journal submissions. We have made all of our algorithms and computer programs publicly available so that the public can make use of the technology resulted from this project. Early warning of the two negative outcomes (clinical deterioration and hospital readmission) has the potential to improve the overall administration of healthcare in the US. Unexpected deaths of hospitalized patient are common and costly for US healthcare. In addition, the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act has targeted hospital readmissions as a key area for intervention. A study on Medicare claims identified that 19.6% of patients are readmitted within 30 days of hospital discharge with an annual cost to tax payers of $15-17 billion per year. Our research and clinical study in this project result in improved clinical outcomes, and can potentially reduce both patient mortality rates and healthcare costs. It addresses a major medical, societal, and governmental concern which has the potential to improve the overall administration of healthcare in the United States.
